data.name: Edge Zone
data.description: frontline communication layer in the crisis response system

data.name: Cloud Broker
data.description: central messaging hub of the system.

data.name: Crisis Command Operators
data.description: centralized operations team responsible for issuing, monitoring, and adjusting rescue missions

data.name: Drone Bridge Broker
data.description: local MQTT bridge that receives published messages from edge devices and forwards emergency alerts and environmental data to the cloud-level MQTT broker.

threats.title: Sensitive Data Disclosure
threats.description: Using packet-sniffing tools, an attacker on the same network intercepts unencrypted MQTT traffic. GPS coordinates, operational telemetry, and mission-critical directives are just a few examples of the intercepted data that could jeopardize the privacy of rescue operations and leave them open to sabotage or spying.
threats.mitigation: use TLS encryption for all MQTT communication, implement VPN or network segmentation to isolate broker traffic, avoid transmitting sensitive data in plain MQTT payloads, apply certificate pinning and enforce modern cipher suites.

data.name: MQTT Core Broker
data.description: central message broker that handles all MQTT messages in the system and subscribes to critical topics and routes messages to relevant clients

threats.title: MQTT Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker can impersonate a rescue drone if they have access to the MQTT broker and are aware of legitimate client IDs. The attacker may interfere with search and rescue efforts by injecting erroneous telemetry data or deceptive command messages by imitating a genuine drone's client ID. In crisis response settings, this danger compromises the veracity of messages and may result in ill-informed choices.
threats.mitigation: enforce mutual TLS on the broker to authenticate clients, implement client ID uniqueness and session takeover protection, use username/password or certificate-based authentication, and enable broker logging to detect unusual reconnections or spoof attempts.

threats.title: DoS on MQTT Broker
threats.description: A rogue client uses a lot of CPU and memory resources by bombarding the MQTT broker with a lot of unnecessary or distorted messages. This may paralyze communication between drones and the command center by delaying or dropping valid rescue messages. This hazard has the potential to seriously reduce response effectiveness in a real-time crisis situation.
threats.mitigation: configure rate-limiting per client/IP, enable connection throttling and message quota settings on the broker, deploy a reverse proxy to filter malicious MQTT traffic, and monitor broker health with Grafana alerts and auto-restart policies.

threats.title: Unauthorized Drone Control
threats.description: Due to inadequate access restriction on the MQTT broker, an unauthorized user is able to access drone control topics. This enables the attacker to give unapproved drone commands, like landing, movement, or mission abortion. The physical security of operations may be jeopardized by such an attack, which could also put citizens or responders in the impacted area in threat.
threats.mitigation: define topic-level ACLs to restrict who can publish to command topics, enable authorization plugins, audit command traffic through Grafana and database logging, and separate control topics with write-only rules for trusted operators.

threats.title: Configuration Backdoors
threats.description: To obtain administrative access, an attacker takes advantage of the MQTT broker's default or weak credentials. Once inside, they may change the broker's configuration to permit continuous backdoor access, disable logs, or change topic access rights. The infrastructure of the rescue system is compromised in terms of both control and integrity by such configuration tampering.
threats.mitigation: change or disable all default credentials upon deployment, enforce strong password policies and multi-factor authentication for admin access, monitor configuration changes via audit logging, and regularly scan for open ports and test broker security posture using automated tools.

data.name: Subscriber Service
data.description: backend system that listens to MQTT topics and inserts relevant data into the rescue data DB using SQL commands

data.name:
Grafana Ops
Dashboard
data.description: real-time monitoring and visualization dashboard, interfaces bidirectionally with the crisis command unit, and queries the rescue data DB for historical or live mission data

data.name: Command Unit
data.description: central node that receives operational input from the crisis Command Unit and sends mission or drone commands to the MQTT Core Broker via topics. also sends internal operational status updates to grafana for tracking and visual alerts

data.name: Survivor
data.description: person in distress who sends emergency signals.

threats.title: Log Tampering
threats.description: MQTT activity logs are altered or erased by a malevolent insider with access to the logging system in order to conceal illegal conduct. To conduct reliable forensic investigations, logs must be externally duplicated or immutable. Because of this, system accountability is undermined and malevolent activity might go unnoticed.
threats.mitigation: push logs to a remote write-once storage or tamper-proof system, enable log integrity monitoring with checksum verification, restrict log access via role-based access control, and schedule automated log backups and store offsite
